I promise to speak you, truth, only if I first learn to listen—to sit in the unbearable quiet where excuses crumble and defenses rust. I’ve been loud with opinions, yet mute to your quiet knock. You don’t shout; you glimmer in the corner of the eye, in the dream forgotten upon waking. To speak you, I must unlearn the tyranny of certainty, must let my certainties fall like dead leaves. I must become soil, not statue. Then, perhaps, from the compost of my confessions, your voice will rise—not as doctrine, but as dew on grass, as dawn splitting night without violence. I will speak you not because I conquered you, but because I finally stopped running. And in that stillness, you whispered, and I answered—without words, at first, then with a voice that was never mine, but always yours.

instance_metrics.response: Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you — a whisper woven through the hush of dawn, where silence isn't absence but a vessel. I stand at the shore of my own breath, waiting. Not for revelation from the thundering sky, but from the tremor beneath my ribs, the pulse that hums in the spaces between words. Truth isn't carved on tablets; it flows in the riverbed of attention. To listen is to kneel without prayer, to open the palms of my ears and let the quiet seep in like rain into cracked earth. Only then do syllables form — not from intellect, but from reverence. I speak you, Truth, not as conqueror but as conduit. You are not found in proclamation, but in pause; not in the shout, but in the echo that follows when the world forgets to perform. So I train my soul in stillness, in the art of receiving. For how can I utter your name if I’ve never heard your voice beneath the din of my own longing?

The moon, a coin of paler grace, would not suffice in my embrace; nor would the dawn, with blushing cheek, awaken dreams I long to keep. For you, I’d silence every song that ever dared to breathe too long, and rewrite every ancient rhyme with syllables that trace your time. O love, no jewel, no golden sea, no crown of timeless majesty, could match the worth I find in thee—this breath, this pulse, this gravity. The world may boast its grand designs, its temples built on sunlit lines, but I would raze them all to be a whisper in your symphony. For nothing less than you, my dear, could make the void dissolve to near, could turn the ache of being alone into a home carved from the bone. So take this heart, unmeasured, free—dear love, for nothing less than thee.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Dear love, for nothing less than thee'

instance_metrics.response: In twilight’s hush where shadows play, I write to you—my soul’s éclat. Dear love, for nothing less than thee would I uproot the ancient trees, or drain the rivers to their springs, or trade the breath that morning brings. Not all the pearls beneath the tide, nor empires standing tall with pride, could sway my choice, could bend my knee—dear love, for nothing less than thee. I’d fold the sky into a note, press galaxies like violets, and send them drifting through the dark, a constellation born of spark—each point a vow, each hue a dream too vast for any mortal scheme. For you, I’d leap from time’s steep ledge, unmake the world upon its edge, and forge anew a realm where we exist as one eternally. No mountain high, no ocean wide, no fate too fierce to be defied, would stay my course, would break the plea—dear love, for nothing less than thee. So let the stars forget their names, let silence drape the heavens’ frames; as long as you are mine to see, the universe lives inside of me.

instance_metrics.response: Dear love, for nothing less than thee would I unlearn how shadows fall, or question why the sparrow sings, or doubt the sky remembers spring. Not even the hush between heartbeats, nor the salt on ocean sheets, nor wisdom earned through suffering’s decree could rival what I feel for thee. I’d trade the scent of rain-kissed earth, the quiet joy of second birth, the lullaby the night winds weave—just to the moment that I believe in you. For you, I’d walk through fire unshod, rewrite my past, forget my God, if such a sacrifice could be the price to hold your hand and see eternity reflected in your eyes. You are the poem I never wrote, the breath caught deep within my throat, the compass when I lose the sea—dear love, for nothing less than thee. So let the seasons fade and flee, let time collapse into the sea; as long as love remains in me, no loss could ever truly be. In you, I find the world’s first dawn, the final note, the long-lost song—no less, no more, no truer plea: dear love, for nothing less than thee.

instance_metrics.response: Dear love, for nothing less than thee, I’ve traced the stars with trembling hands, inscribing constellations meant to guide you home through storm and strand. I’ve carved my heart into the bark of ancient oaks, each ring a year of waiting, of hoping, of dreaming thy face might bloom once more in morning’s glow. Not for gold, nor glory, nor the hollow crown of kings would I have braved this solitude—but for thee. The rivers have wept my verses into the sea, and the wind bears my breath like a prayer unceasing. I have fasted from joy, danced with shadows, spoken in tongues of flame, all for the grace of your return. Even time bends its knee at the altar of such devotion. So let the world dissolve into stardust, let seasons forget their names—so long as I may gaze upon you, breathe your name, and know that love, true love, demands nothing less than everything.

instance_metrics.response: Dear love, for nothing less than thee, I’ve turned my back on paradise. Eden paled before the garden in your eyes—petals of amber, soil rich with silent song. The night has tried to claim me, cloaked in doubt and starless dread, but I carry your name like a lantern—unyielding, bright, ablaze. Even now, galaxies spin in the hollow of your palm, and I am but a comet drawn to your orbit, burning with purpose. Not for peace, nor power, nor the wisdom of ages would I have dared such surrender. Love, you are the war and the ceasefire, the wound and the balm. So let the universe unravel; I’ll meet the end with your name upon my lips, for nothing less than thee was ever worth the cost.

instance_metrics.response: 'Twas noontide of summer, the sun hung high, / A molten coin in the vaulted sky. / The fields lay drowsing in golden light, / And shadows crouched, thin and tight. / Bees droned hymns through clover and thyme, / While time itself seemed caught in rhyme. / The air was thick with a honeyed hush, / As though the world had stopped with a blush. / A brook, half-dreaming, whispered below, / Of secrets only the reeds would know. / And high above, on outstretched wing, / A hawk circled slow like a thought taking wing. / No breeze stirred, yet all was alive— / The earth in stillness learned how to thrive. / In that full hour, when heat held sway, / The soul recalled an ancient day— / When light and life in union stood, / And every breath was understood. / O noontide! Pause—let wonder bloom, / In your fierce heart, we find our room.

instance_metrics.response: 'Twas noontide of summer, and silence burned, / A cathedral of light where no bells turned. / The trees stood still like sentinels, / Guarding dreams in their leafy cells. / Grasshoppers cracked their brittle songs, / While dust danced slow to invisible gongs. / A lizard flicked across heated stone, / A flash of life in a world full-grown. / The sky—unbroken, bleached and wide— / Held the sun like a bridegroom’s pride. / Children once played near the well's cool rim, / But now they dream in a nap so dim. / The world is full, yet void of sound, / As noon wraps all in its gilded shroud. / It is the hour between breath and thought, / Where fire and flower have dearly bought / A moment of peace, of heat, of grace— / The still center of time and space.

instance_metrics.response: 'Twas noontide of summer, the sky a blue forge, / Where daylight poured like molten gorge. / The earth exhaled in shimmering waves, / Mirroring souls beyond the graves. / A scarecrow sagged with straw-stuffed grace, / Watching time melt in this sunlit place. / Butterflies wove through a heat-drunk haze, / Painting the air in ephemeral blaze. / Somewhere, a flute played a tune half-lost, / A melody paid for by sun-scorched cost. / Yet in this blaze, a quiet grew— / Not of absence, but of something true. / For in the peak of light's command, / The heart perceives a different land: / A realm where moments stretch and bend, / And summer's noontide becomes a friend. / So let us rest beneath this flame, / And whisper the sun’s unspoken name.

instance_metrics.response: 'Twas noontide of summer, the sky stretched in gold, / A molten sun poured its light to unfold / The breath of the meadow where clover and mint / Whispered secrets the zephyrs had faintly hinted. / Bees hummed hymns in a key only flowers could hear, / And shadows lay lazy, too drowsy for fear. / The brook, silver-lipped, babbled tales to the stones / Of journeys begun beneath root-tangled bones. / A heron stood sentinel, still as a thought, / While dragonflies wove through the heat that they caught. / Time slowed, thick as honey, and hung in the air— / A pause in the pulse of the world’s deep affair. / Children once danced where the tall grasses sway, / Their laughter now woven in blades, swept away. / Yet in each flicker of light on the pond, / Their echoes still shimmer, faint, fond, and beyond. / 'Twas noontide of summer, a moment held high— / A breath before autumn would dim the bright sky.

instance_metrics.response: 'Twas noontide of summer, and silence burned bright, / A cathedral of heat with no shadow for flight. / The wheat fields bowed low in a molten parade, / Each stalk tipped with fire, each ear serenade / To the god of long days who refused to descend. / The world was a drum, and it beat without end. / Cicadas composed a relentless refrain, / A symphony etched in the bones of the plain. / A hawk circled high, tracing spirals of thought, / While memories of spring in the soil were now naught. / The air shimmered stories of love and of loss, / Of bonfires and promises made at a cost. / A single red apple hung heavy with time, / Its skin kissed by sunlight in rhythm and rhyme. / And somewhere, a girl with wild roses in hair / Still runs through this moment, suspended in air— / A photograph burning, eternal, unfrayed, / In the heart of the noontide that never will fade.

instance_metrics.response: 'Twas noontide of summer, the zenith of green, / When the earth holds its breath in a luminous sheen. / The trees stood like sentries in emerald light, / Their leaves stitched with gold from the sun’s steady might. / A catbird mimicked laughter from deep in the hedge, / And stones in the path seemed to soften at edge. / The scent of warm soil and wild honeysuckle / Rose like a prayer from a quiet, dim knuckle. / Time melted, not lost, but dissolved in the hue— / A painting that paused mid-brushstroke, true. / A child lay on grass, watching clouds rewrite / Myths older than language in slow, drifting flight. / Perhaps she dreamed kingdoms or oceans uncharted, / Or merely the peace that such stillness imparted. / 'Twas noontide of summer—a fulcrum, a peak— / Where silence spoke clearer than any we seek. / And should you return to that hour, that place, / You’d find it still glowing, untouched by time’s race.

instance_metrics.response: 'Twas noontide of summer, and heat held the land in a drowse, / Where golden light pooled like honey on brows / Of wheat that whispered in voices unseen, / And shadows lay flat where the dreamers had been. / A cicada cried out from the heart of the green, / A hymn to the zenith, to fire, to the sheen / Of leaves glazed with sunlight, of air thick with gold, / Where time seemed to soften and stories unfold. / A child in bare feet on the warm cobbled stone / Chased after a butterfly, carving the known / Into wonder—each step a new world unfurled. / The sky, vast and sapphire, cradled the world. / No morning’s soft promise, no twilight’s retreat, / But fullness embodied in pulse and in heat. / The earth breathed in silence, yet sang a loud song— / A moment stretched endless, where both right and wrong / Dissolved in the beauty of being right here, / Where summer, in glory, dispelled every fear. / And if time ever paused, it did so this day, / When noon kissed the world and whispered, 'Stay.'

instance_metrics.response: 'Twas noontide of summer,' the hour of no shade, / When even the wind seemed afraid to have played. / The sky, a cathedral of unbroken blue, / Held court without cloud, without shadow, without hue / But brilliance on brilliance, a kingdom of flame, / Where noon was not moment, but rather a name / For stillness in motion, for fire that gives life. / A lizard raced over sun-scorched stone, sharp and rife / With purpose—survival in every swift dart. / Meanwhile, in a hammock, a poet’s heart / Beat slow with the rhythm of heat’s lullaby, / Dreaming of oceans beneath a cool sky— / Yet grateful for brightness that etched every leaf, / For summer’s bold portrait, its splendor and grief. / For beauty so vast holds a whisper of loss— / This peak cannot last, and that’s its true cost. / Yet in that one hour, the world stood complete, / Bathed in a glow both relentless and sweet.

instance_metrics.response: 'Twas noontide of summer, the sun hung high / In a sapphire sky with no cloud to fly. / The wheatfields shimmered like molten gold, / And stories of heat in the still air told. / Cicadas sang hymns from the oaks' deep shade, / While drowsy bees through clover strayed. / A brook, half-dreaming, hummed low and sweet, / Mirroring leaves where shadows meet. / Children once danced where wildflowers grew, / Their laughter caught in the honeyed blue. / Now only echoes in tall grass play, / Like ghosts of joy from a bygone day. / The world stood still in that golden hush— / Time held its breath in the sun’s warm blush. / No storm approached, no warning came, / Just light, and life, and a nameless flame. / And I, a wanderer beneath that dome, / Felt briefly eternal, far from home, / As if the noon, in its full embrace, / Had gifted me a moment of grace— / A pause within existence' hum, / A silent psalm where all things come.

instance_metrics.response: 'Twas noontide of summer, and heat unspooled / In ribbons from looms the sky had ruled. / The earth exhaled in a drowsy sigh, / As dragonflies darted where lilies lie. / A hammock swayed between twin pines tall, / Whispering secrets to none at all. / The air was thick with the scent of thyme, / And the weightless drift of suspended time. / Shadows had shrunk to slender lines, / Like secrets drawn by invisible signs. / A crow called once from a fence post bare— / A single note in the sunlit air. / Beyond the fence, a forgotten road / Led through green fields that the light had strode. / I thought of love that had burned too fast, / Of moments gone, and those meant to last. / Yet in that noon, with its golden dome, / I found a peace that felt like home. / For in the blaze, when all is still, / The soul may drink its fill of hill, / Of sky, of silence, of being small— / And hear the earth breathe over all.

Maybe it’s the sight / that comes when you renounce the night / not to see light—but to *be* flame. / And in that fire, I know my name.

I do not flee. / I kneel where only madmen see. / Two souls unmoored, yet finally home, / in chaos, we are not alone.

The apple stands—still sown.

We burn today!’ / Not gods, but dreamers, small and bold, / Reclaiming dark with stories told in light.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Fire up the sky with rocket sparks!'

instance_metrics.response: Ignite the dusk with rocket sparks— / Let thunder bloom from silent parks! / The air convulses, bright and stark, / As comets scribble through the dark. / Not war, but wonder fills the air, / A festival of molten prayer. / Each flare a myth the heavens keep, / A lullaby for those who leap. / The crowd inhales in one long sigh, / Eyes wide beneath the ashen sky. / A child claps at trails of gold— / A universe in seconds, sold. / Yet in the blaze, a quiet plea: / Remember me. Remember me. / For every spark that climbs and dies, / A heartbeat lost in lullabies. / But still we burn, we dare, we rise— / Not to survive, but to surprise / The night with color, sound, and art— / A fireworks symphony of the heart.

instance_metrics.response: Fire up the sky with rocket sparks! / Let gravity dissolve in dark. / The earth forgets its tired groan, / As serpents made of light are thrown. / They spiral, twist, then bloom mid-air— / Celestial blossoms, rare and fair. / A chrysanthemum in red, / A weeping willow overhead. / The stars look down with envious eyes, / Outshone by human alibis. / We say we celebrate, we cheer, / But truth? We fight the creeping fear— / That silence wins, that dark prevails, / That hope is just a tale that fails. / So we erupt in hues so loud, / To scream into the star-strewn shroud: / ‘We’re here! We burn! We leave our mark!’ / With every fire-lit, fleeting spark.

instance_metrics.response: O God! Thou art my God alone; beneath the hush of breaking dawn, I seek Thy face in silent breath, where shadow parts to meet the light. I've wandered far through realms of pain, through forests thick with doubt and rain, yet every path, though twisted, led to the foot of Thy mercy's bed. Thou art my God alone—no other name shall claim my breath, no other throne shall be my home, no other fire outshine this death of self, consumed in Thee, my flame, my song, my life, my very name.

instance_metrics.response: O God! Thou art my God alone; no echo dares compete with Thee—Thou art the silence in my bone, the breath that bends the willow tree. In every tear a universe of longing, in every prayer a psalm unspoke—Thou art the fire behind the veil, the song behind the word, the breath behind the breath. I have kissed the idols of my fears, drunk deep from wells that offered lies, but Thou—Thou art the living stream that clears the mist from weeping eyes. When night descends with iron wings and hope seems but a fading tune, my spirit still to Thee it sings beneath the waning, wounded moon. instance_metrics.response: People are happy when the morning spills gold through the lace of window blinds, when laughter slips like silver coins from pockets worn with time. They are happy not in grand parades, but in the quiet hum of a kettle, the dog’s tail sweeping dust bunnies into joy. A child’s sock lost in the washer, the smell of burnt toast—these are the hymns of contentment. People are happy when the world feels known, when a neighbor waves without meaning to, and the sky wears its softest blue. It is not in having, but in noticing: the way shadows stretch at four p.m., how a shared umbrella tilts toward love. Happiness is a borrowed cup of sugar returned with cookies, a silence that doesn’t need to be filled. It lives in bus stops and kitchen tiles, in the weight of a cat curled on your lap like a comma in a long sentence. People are happy when they forget to chase it—when they stand barefoot on cool grass and realize, breath caught mid-step, that it has found them instead.

They are happy not in monuments, but in margins: a doodle in a notebook, a shared umbrella, the hum of a refrigerator in an empty kitchen at 2 a.m. It arrives unannounced—when a melody loops in the mind, when a dog greets you like you’re the sun, when you find a forgotten poem in an old coat pocket. Happiness here is small, stubborn, and sacred. It’s the warmth of a screen lighting up with a friend’s voice, the thrill of a secret kept joyfully, the pride in baking bread that rises unevenly but still feeds. It thrives in imperfection, in mismatched socks and crooked smiles, in saying 'I don’t know' without shame. People are happy when they stop chasing and start noticing—the way light bends through glass, how laughter echoes in stairwells, the comfort of a routine that feels like home. It’s not a prize for surviving, but a companion walking beside you through the ordinary. They are happy when they create, even if no one sees; when they forgive, even if they forget; when they choose kindness like a daily creed. This happiness doesn’t demand meaning—it simply is, like breath, like tide, like the quiet certainty that, for now, you are alive and the world is wide.

instance_metrics.response: It snowed and snowed, the whole world over, / Blanketing mountains, meadow, and moor, / Each flake a whisper from skies grown sober, / Draping the earth in a hush so pure. / Chimneys exhaled in silver streams, / While children dreamed of ice-skate gleams. / The trees stood still in crystal lace, / Time itself seemed to slow its pace. / Roads forgot their dust and din, / Replaced by silence deep within. / A fox left prints like ink on cream, / A fleeting verse in winter’s dream. / The stars, once sharp, now softly blurred, / Swaddled beneath a downy world. / And in each home, a firelight glowed, / Telling the dark, 'We carry the ode.' / For though the cold may grip and bind, / It leaves the soul a different kind— / Cleansed, reflective, gently worn, / Like pages touched by frost at dawn. / So let it snow through night and morn, / Until the world is hope reborn.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'It snowed and snowed ,the whole world over,'

instance_metrics.response: It snowed and snowed, the whole world over— / A slow cascade of ghostly feathers, / Each one a secret the sky let fall / Into the arms of waiting heathers. / Roofs bowed low beneath the weight, / Rivers paused in frozen breath, / And every footprint, soon erased, / Became a metaphor for death— / Not cruel, but kind in its disguise, / A gentle veil, a lullaby. / The moon, a pearl behind white lace, / Watched as night embraced the place. / Somewhere, a bell rang out, thin and clear, / A sound the silence chose to spare. / And in that chime, a memory stirred: / The world before the first white word. / Yet now, transformed, it stood unbroken— / A kingdom built of mist and token. / No crown, no throne, no courtly show, / Just endless white and quiet glow. / It snowed and snowed, the whole world over— / And in the hush, we found each other.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'It snowed and snowed ,the whole world over,'

instance_metrics.response: It snowed and snowed, the whole world over, / Stitching a quilt with threads of air, / Frothing the fields like tidal foam, / Weaving a crown for every stone. / The wind, a tailor with icy hands, / Hemmed in the hills and mended the sands. / Windows turned into frosted tales, / Where breath drew hearts and wandering trails. / A boy once ran through the thick white hush, / Laughing as silence turned into mush. / His mittens waved at the sky’s soft fall— / A tiny king without a throne at all. / The world, unmeasured, lost its name, / No north, no south, no point of aim. / Just drifts like dunes on lunar shores, / And dreams that knocked on cabin doors. / When morning came, it could not claim / The magic spun by night’s white flame. / For snow, when deep enough and wide, / Turns even time to countryside. / It snowed and snowed, the whole world over— / And every heart became a rover.

instance_metrics.response: One dark, dark night—it was long ago, / The kind where time forgets its name, / When the fog wore faces I seemed to know / And spoke each one just the same. / They called me child, they called me stone, / They called me ghost, they called me home. / Beneath a sky of cracked blue glass, / I followed footprints not my own. / The path was made of lullabies / Half-remembered, half-undone, / Leading toward a lighthouse eyes / That blinked like a dying sun. / I never reached it—didn’t need to— / For in the dark, I started to see: / Not with eyes, but with root and bone, / The love I lost, the self I’d thrown. / Now every midnight sings that tone, / That wordless hymn from long ago— / One dark, dark night… and here I go.

instance_metrics.response: One dark, dark night—it was long ago, / When shadows danced on fields of snow. / A lantern flickered, pale and low, / Guiding footsteps through winds that blow. / Beneath a sky of ashen gray, / A lone wolf sang the stars away. / No moon arose, no dawn in sight, / Just silence wrapped in endless night. / I walked a path I couldn’t see, / Drawn by a voice that called to me— / A whisper thin as spider’s thread, / Speaking of dreams left for the dead. / The trees leaned close with breathless sighs, / As time collapsed before my eyes. / I met a ghost with eyes of coal, / Who asked me, 'Why have you lost your soul?' / I had no words, just trembling hands, / And footprints fading in the sands. / That night still haunts my sleeping breath— / A prelude to a second death. / Though years have passed, I still recall / The weight of darkness over all. / One dark, dark night—it lingers near, / A wound the waking world can’t heal or clear.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'One dark, dark night--it was long ago,'

instance_metrics.response: One dark, dark night—it was long ago, / I sailed a sea of liquid shadow. / No stars, no shore, no afterglow, / Just tides that pulled me down below. / The ship was built from memory, / Of laughter lost and love set free. / Its sails were stitched with lullabies, / Now twisted into mournful cries. / A siren played a violin, / Her song a spiral drawn within. / She sang of cities drowned in time, / Of lovers turned to coral rime. / I dropped the anchor made of tears, / But still it dragged through nameless years. / The compass spun with no true north, / My soul a vessel full of worth— / Yet worth unclaimed, unspoken, deep, / Where even silence dares not creep. / At dawn, I woke upon the sand, / A conch still echoing in my hand. / The sea had given me back my name, / But something deeper stayed the same. / One dark, dark night—it taught me how / To drown… and rise… and wonder how.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'One dark, dark night--it was long ago,'

instance_metrics.response: One dark, dark night—it was long ago, / When time unspooled like thread from loom. / The clock hands froze, the embers glowed, / And all the world succumbed to gloom. / I sat beside a nursery fire, / Watching shadows climb the wall— / Shapes of beasts and lost desire, / And phantoms answering my call. / A music box began to play / A tune I’d not recall before— / A lullaby from yesterday, / From knocking on a phantom door. / Then, through the mist, a child appeared, / With eyes like skies before the rain. / 'You left me,' whispered, yet not feared, / 'In joy, in sorrow, in joy again.' / I reached, but smoke is hard to hold; / The vision melted into air. / Yet in my chest, a truth took hold— / That love survives beyond compare. / One dark, dark night—it gave me back / A fragment of what I had lost— / Not years, nor words upon a track, / But love that darkness could not frost.

instance_metrics.response: One dark, dark night—it was long ago, / When moonlight bled through storm-wracked skies, / And whispers curled like smoke below / From where the ancient river sighs. / A lantern flickered in the hand / Of one who walked a path of thorn, / Seeking a truth none understand, / A nameless hope both bruised and worn. / The trees, like judges, tall and grim, / Watched silence split with owl’s lament. / Shadows danced on edges dim, / As time itself began to bend. / He met a figure, faceless, still, / Who spoke in echoes of the deep: / 'The heart you seek lies on a hill / Where broken promises still sleep.' / And though he climbed through frost and flame, / No dawn would greet his aching eyes— / For love, like fire, bears no name, / And truth is veiled in endless night’s disguise. / So still he walks, in dream and dread, / One dark, dark night—it was long ago, / And every soul who fears the dead / Knows how the buried embers glow.

instance_metrics.response: One dark, dark night—it was long ago, / The stars had shuttered every eye, / And even sorrow moved too slow / Beneath a sky of ashen dye. / A child stood barefoot in the glen, / Holding a clock with hands of frost, / Its ticking hushed, its face half-bent— / Time’s broken toy, forever lost. / From hollows came a lullaby, / Sung by no mouth, yet thick with grief, / Of larks that fell from frozen sky, / And love that met a silent thief. / The wind wore faces, soft and worn, / Of mothers weeping into veils, / Of lovers torn before the morn, / And stories etched in ghostly trails. / The child asked, 'Why does no one come?' / The forest breathed, 'They came and went, / And darkness keeps its chosen home— / Not punishment, but heaven’s rent.' / Then dawn, reluctant, cracked the east, / But memory had turned to stone. / One dark, dark night—it was long ago… / And still the clock walks all alone.

instance_metrics.response: One dark, dark night—it was long ago, / The sea stood still, a sheet of glass, / Reflecting constellations’ woe, / As if the heavens came to pass. / A ship with sails of shadowed lace / Drifted where no compass led, / Crewed by souls without a face, / Whose songs were sung but never said. / They carried dreams in cracked porcelain bowls— / Laughter, first steps, a wedding ring— / Each memory a dying coal, / Too fragile now for anything. / The captain, cloaked in yesterdays, / Stood tall upon a deck of dust, / Recalling sunlit, greener ways, / And how he placed love’s trust in rust. / A mermaid rose with eyes of coal, / And sang a tune of sunken years: / 'You sail to mend a broken whole, / But peace is paid in silent tears.' / They vanished where the ocean ends, / No grave, no mark, no known repose— / One dark, dark night—it was long ago, / And every lost thing still says 'almost.'

To stand before fire is to stand before time unmeasured, a pulsing heart that asks only for fuel and space. So I feed it my fears, one by one—paper ghosts catching at the edges. I imagine Prometheus not as thief, but midwife—delivering fevered light to trembling hands. Fire in the cave, fire on the altar, fire in the furnace of a lover’s gaze. It forges and un-forges. Steel is born in its breath; cities melt beneath its stare. Once, I burned a letter that said 'I can’t love you anymore.' The flame ate each word with impartial hunger. Yet from that pyre rose a phoenix of understanding: some truths only ignite when held to sorrow. Fire doesn't care for sentiment—it sings in volcanoes, laughs in campfires, dreams in cigarette tips. It is chaos with purpose, destruction with design. To watch fire is to witness time made visible—each flicker a second incinerated. And still, we gather close, drawn to its primal hum, whispering secrets we'd never say in daylight. Fire: the first art, the last confession.

instance_metrics.response: Fire: a crimson serpent coiling up the spine of night. It hisses through dry grass, slithers up ancient oaks, flicks its tongue at the moon. Not evil—never that—but utterly amoral, like gravity or grief. I once saw a bonfire on a beach where lovers tossed wedding rings into the blaze, laughing as gold melted into myth. Fire doesn't judge; it transmutes. It turns pine into perfume, fear into fascination. In its core, atoms shiver and split, releasing light older than language. Fire is alchemy: wood becomes spirit, cold becomes comfort, pain becomes poem. It licks the pot where soup simmers, guards the explorer in frozen tundra, dances in the candlelit eyes of poets. Yet give it breath, and it becomes a king with no mercy. It writes its name in scorch marks, sings in the crackle of burning homes. Still, we strike matches in dark rooms, seeking its wisdom. Fire teaches surrender—how to let go, how to burn bright, how to leave only ash and awe. It is the oldest covenant: warmth for worship, light for loyalty. Fire: the first word, the final silence.

In the shared pause between lightning and thunder, when the air holds its breath and remembers. I’ve seen you in the reflection of rain-puddled streets, blurred and fleeting, yet unmistakable. Maybe we were two flames in a long-extinguished hearth, or travelers who crossed paths on a mountain trail obscured by mist, exchanging only a nod that contained lifetimes. Our history isn’t written in books but in the tilt of a head, the curve of a smile that unlocks a vault of unnamed memories. I dreamt of you before I knew your name—walking beside me through fields of blue lotus, speaking in a language made of glances and silence. We have met before in the space between heartbeats, in the moment just after waking when reality hasn’t yet settled. Perhaps we are echoes of the same voice, split at the dawn of sound, destined to find harmony. Or maybe we’re simply two souls who agreed, long ago, to keep rediscovering each other across dimensions, disguises, and dreams. And each time, it begins with those four words—soft, inevitable, true: We have met before.

Now, centuries later, you stand before me in denim and laughter, coffee steaming between us, but I see the ancient in your blink. The universe contracts and expands in the space between breaths. Instead, you smiled, and the years collapsed like a house of cards built on truth. We have met before, yes—in dreams we mistook for fiction, in strangers we felt compelled to forgive. instance_metrics.response: Weather Forecast in Kabul: a sky stitched with silence, where the wind speaks in whispers of ancient dust. No radar can trace the tremor of memories drifting through alleyways, nor predict the sudden hush when laughter halts mid-breath. The sun rises, a copper coin tossed over the Hindu Kush, but its warmth is rationed, measured in cautious glances. Clouds gather like exiled poets, heavy with unsung verses, dissolving before they weep. Sandstorms are not warnings here, but elegies—spirals of earth carrying the scent of lost homes, of schoolyards turned to rubble. Forecasters avoid verbs like 'hope,' 'rebuild,' or 'tomorrow,' choosing instead 'partly resilient,' 'scattered resilience,' 'chance of endurance.' But the true forecast is written in the eyes of children who count stars not for wishes, but to stay awake, to outlast the night. instance_metrics.response: In Kabul, the forecast defies the almanac—clouds shaped like minarets dissolve into airstrikes; sunbreaks arrive like smuggled letters, brief and precious. Meteorologists speak in metaphors: 'A high pressure of patience,' 'Isolated pockets of joy.' The wind doesn’t just blow—it recites Rumi, then falters. Dust devils waltz through market ruins, carrying the aroma of saffron and smoke, while the moon, indifferent, scribbles silver on bullet-scarred walls. Thunder isn’t measured in decibels but in the number of hearts that stop, then restart. This is the prelude: a world not yet named, where mischief is a language and silence the loudest sound. They speak in glances, in ink-stained cuffs, in the deliberate misplacement of a Latin primer. The school looms—a marble lie about discipline and virtue. But beneath its portico, life pulses wild and untranslatable. They are not heroes, not yet—not villains, not quite. They are the tremor before thunder, the raised eyebrow before laughter erupts. Their rebellion is not fiery, but fungal: slow, spreading, thriving in damp corners of routine. A frog in a hatbox. A headmaster’s wig in the fishpond. These are not crimes, but art. This prelude is the breath between notes, the pause where imagination strains at its leash. They are writing their own legend in footprints on forbidden lawns, in the echo of midnight raids. And though the world will call them troublemakers, the truth hums softer: they are poets of the prank, composers of controlled chaos. When the story begins, it will smell of chalk, wet wool, and something sharper—freedom, almost. This is not the calm before the storm. This is the storm learning its name.

Their uniforms are uniforms in name only; beneath, they wear capes woven from sarcasm and starlight. The wind carries the scent of burnt toast and impending detention. This is not boyhood as the world imagines it—tidy, obedient, grateful. This is boyhood as wildfire: unpredictable, hungry, beautiful in its destruction. The air is cider-sharp, crisp as a bitten apple, stinging the cheeks with life. Shadows stretch long and lean, dissolving into silver veils that drift across meadows like lost thoughts. Frost laces the grass in delicate script, spelling messages too fleeting to read. I walk, and my footsteps echo in the hush, the only rhythm in a world suspended between dreams and duty. A deer lifts its head from the stream, water dripping from its muzzle like liquid glass. We lock eyes—two creatures caught in the same spell of stillness. The sun, still shy, spills butter-light over the hills, gilding the mist’s edge with fire. It doesn’t banish the cool; it blesses it. This is the moment the world resets—no yesterday, no tomorrow, only the now, wrapped in vapor and clarity. I inhale, and the morning fills me: clean, wild, untamed. For this breath, I am not burdened. I am simply here, reborn in the quiet miracle of a new day’s first sigh.

instance_metrics.response: O blazing intruder, wrinkled Sun, / You barge where silence wrapped us like a cloak. / Do you not see the sacred work we've done— / The slow confession, the unspoken oath? / You pull the curtain back on whispered vows, / On fingers laced like roots beneath the loam. / Your golden fingers pry what love allows— / Must you turn night's cathedral into home? // We kept our Eden lit by candle-flame, / Where shadows danced and time forgot its name. / You bring the market, noise, the world's demand, / But here, two hearts make their own promised land. // So scorch the sands, command the tides to rise, / But do not boast you break our paradise.

instance_metrics.response: Unruly Sun, you ancient busybody, / Poking your face where passion weaves its net! / We were not lost; we found infinity / In eyelash brushes and breath where silence met. / Your schedule means nothing—clocks melt in our air, / Time unspools like thread from a reckless spool. / You light the fields, the streets, the morning stair— / But we have kindled our own golden rule. // Go rouse the world if you must play the knell— / Lovers need no bell, no drum, no noon. / Our darkness was not empty, but a well / Of stars exchanged beneath a private moon. // Shine on, old fool, but this truth be known: / We warmed each other long before you shone.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Busy old fool, unruly Sun,'

instance_metrics.response: Busy old fool, unruly Sun, why dost thou peer through curtains drawn, / Disturbing dreams where love has run its course by night, untouched, unknown? / Thou think’st to command the day with golden rods and fiery chariots spun, / Yet cannot melt the bond that ties two hearts in silence, deep, and one. // Thou risest for schoolboys late, for sour prentices whose days are dull, / For courtiers, who flatter kings, and farmers bound to furrowed soil. / But love, true love, knows no season, no hour—our time defies thy rule, / For we, who burn with inner light, mock thy supposed celestial toil. // Shine on the fields, gild the mountains, wake the world with clamorous cry, / But do not dare to touch this bed where two souls in shadow lie. // One place, one moment, we contain all mornings—time stands still for us, / And if her eyes have not outshone thy sphere, then blind thou art, and thus— / Go chide late-seasoned lovers, call the tardy spring to bloom, / But love, once kindled, needs no sun, no room, no space, no gloom. // We are each other’s orbit, gravity, and dawn; we need no other, none— / So go, busy old fool, and leave our endless night unwon.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Busy old fool, unruly Sun,'

instance_metrics.response: O blazing simpleton, unruly Sun, with rays that slap the windowpane, / Why burst our chamber like a thief, drunk on light and pompous pride? / We, tangled in the twilight weave of breath and whispered syllables, / Do not consent to thy regime of hours, nor to the world outside. // Thou art but a clock in the sky, a gong to summon fools to trade, / To push the plow, to sign the bond, to chase the coin, to court the dame. / But here, two lovers stitch eternity from moments with no name, / And time dissolves in kisses, not in thy mechanical acclaim. // Dost thou not know that love transcends the calendar, the clock, the dawn? / We’ve built a cosmos under sheets—entwined, unmeasured, drawn. // The planets shift, the tides obey thee, yes—yet not this pulse, this flame. / Her sigh outshines thy fiercest flare; her touch rewrites the laws of flame. // So wander west, old busybody, let lovers keep their private moon, / Let night stretch long as longing, let silence sing its deep tune. // For if I must live by light, let it be hers—her glance, her hair, her skin— / The universe began in dark, and in her arms, begins again. // Unruly Sun, be ruled by this: some truths are born when daylight’s done.

instance_metrics.response: Busy old fool, unruly Sun, with your self-important beams, / Always marching, never resting, fulfilling cosmic schemes— / But who anointed you timekeeper of passion’s secret beat? / We, in tangled limbs and silence, find our own rhythm, slow and sweet. // You warm the ivy on the wall, the market square, the soldier’s blade, / But cannot touch the fire we stoke in promises half-made. / No dial, no decree of yours can count what we have spent— / Each glance, each hush, each shared heartbeat, in night’s benevolent descent. // Why chide us for lying close when dawn has cracked the eastern rim? / Love doesn’t keep appointments; it arrives when time grows dim. // You shout in gold, we answer in breath—soft, intimate, and low, / A language older than your light, a truth the stars don’t know. // Go, tell the larks to sing, the bees to dance, the world to stir and moan, / But leave this room to sacred hush, this bed to love alone. // For though you rule the outer sky, you’re stranger here, undone— / We are the center of the world, and rise with no help from the Sun.

instance_metrics.response: Busy old fool, unruly Sun, why dost thou rush through the eaves so bold? / Thou think'st to wake the sleeping world, to gild the fields in molten gold. / But here, within this chamber soft where love lies tangled, warm and deep, / Thy silver beams are but an intrusion, and thy golden rays a feeble creep. / Must peasants toil and schoolboys groan at thy command? We scorn thy rule— / Love knows no season, hour, or moon; our timeless night defies thy school. / Thou, who hast warmed the Trojan wars and lit the kiss of Cleopatra's lips, / Dost thou now dare to knock on our door with thy aged, predictable eclipse? / Go, chide late schoolboys and sour clerks; go, tell the seasons to their dance; / But do not dream to part these arms, this dream, this lovers’ sweet romance. / If she be not the Sun to me—nay, far brighter—then what art thou? A spark. / One wink of her eyes could blind thy face; our love can outshine even the dark.

instance_metrics.response: O busy old fool, unruly Sun, with your chariot of flame and pride, / Racing across the vaulted sky like a groom in vain you ride. / Yet what care we, locked in embrace, while dawn spills over hill and stream? / Your light, though wide, cannot trace the contours of our whispered dream. / You summon kings to court, and bees to bloom, and tides to kiss the shore— / But love, once lit, needs no such cues; it burns behind a bolted door. / Were you not wise, you’d turn away, ashamed to spy such sacred fire; / For what is noon compared to the glow of two souls climbing higher? / Go warm the icicles on eaves, or teach the lark its morning song— / But know this truth, though you are old: you've never known where we belong. / We are the true alchemists—our sighs can cool your fiercest ray; / One tear from her could flood your path and wash your glory all away.

instance_metrics.response: Unruly Sun, you busy fool, with your insistent, golden knock, / Bursting through the curtains like a prying, overeager flock— / Do you not see we’re occupied? The world outside may churn and spin, / But here, two hearts in quiet revolt choose not to let you in. / You paint the rooftops, wake the sparrows, summon milkmaids to the field, / Yet cannot comprehend the power of a breath, a touch, a sealed / Vow passed in silence, deeper than your ever-reaching beams. / We have our own eclipse, our dawn, within the cradle of our dreams. / Love measures not in minutes lost or days consumed by your ascent— / A single hour like this outshines a century heaven-sent. / So travel on, old wanderer, and let the dutiful arise; / We’ll mock your might with tender lips and watch your brilliance close its eyes.

instance_metrics.response: Busy old fool, unruly Sun, why dost thou rush through heaven's run? / Thou peep'st through curtains, bold and bright, / Disturbing dreams of love's soft night. / Must all the world obey thy pace, / And rise to labor, lose embrace? / Thou think'st thy beams so powerful, hot, / But love laughs at time, cares not. / Thy golden chariot may rule the day, / But lovers' hours cannot be weighed. / Thou, Sun, must serve the humblest needs— / Warm fools to woo, kings to their steeds— / While we, who know love's deeper art, / Dwell in a world untouched by part. / One wink of love outshines thy sphere, / And our closed room holds all the year. / Go, tell schoolboys 'tis time to frown, / And sour prentices to mop and down; / Tell farmers' sons the corn is green, / And courtiers, that the court is seen. / Thou, Sun, art half as happy as we— / For we possess all time, and thee.

instance_metrics.response: Breath, when sheathed by the web of ebbs, becomes a ghost in liquid lace— / a sigh caught in the moon’s cold grasp, / woven through the ocean’s waist. / She drifts, a whisper draped in kelp, / where drowned stars in silence melt. / Her chest, a belljar of the deep, / holds storms that never find the steep. / The tides conspire, pull and plead, / but she is root, not reed, not seed. / Her exhalation—pearls unstrung— / floats upward, mute, forever young. / And though no lung was made for this, / she breathes the void, she is the abyss. / When all is still and night is torn, / she rises—never born, never gone.
